Maybe they meant the oldest cathedral, St Paul's is just a basilica. A cathedral has a higher designation, but I abandoned religion a long time ago so I forget what the differences are. Something to do with the Bishop.
A basilica outranks a cathedral (http://www.bible.ca/catholic-church-hierarchy-organization.htm). See the list under this subheading:
VIII. Catholic buildings and places:

The article says, "The cathedral, what the Archdiocese of Toronto calls the oldest in Toronto still being used for its original purpose, will be rededicated with a new designation from the Vatican".
Pretty sure St. Paul's Basilica is the 'oldest Roman Catholic congregation in Toronto, Ontario, Canada' (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Paul%27s_Basilica). As far as I know it's still being used for its original purpose. In fact, it's where the parishioners of St. Mikes went during the renovations.

Not sure why Meredith wears running shoes. But it certainly appeals to me from a visual perspective more so than clogs/crocs. Gives off a more youthful and a 'I don't take myself so seriously' vibe.

I'm pretty sure Ryan used the phrase 'open source' or at least the word 'open' so I don't think it's you. Can someone else clarify?
So really the issue I have is with the use of antivirus software and the open source movement as a plot device. After thinking about it I realize they needed a product that Joe could sell using fear (as in getting a virus on your PC) as a motivator then swoop in like a saviour with a 'cure' - his software.
But the problem is the time line. Antivirus software was already being distributed for free via BBSs (ironically this was also the main source of viruses pre WWW). And as I mentioned releasing the code as an 'open source' move probably wouldn't have had any real impact.
Edit: spelling and grammar.

Open source was not a really a thing in the time period in which the show takes place. As you can see here:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_open-source_software
there was only about 6 open source projects in the 1980s. It just wasn't part of the culture at the time.
Programmers made shareware or freeware basically as a hobby and distributed it via a BBS. This is exactly how McAfee started:
"The company distributes its antiviral and utilities programs on bulletin board services..."
Source:
https://books.google.ca/books?id=rjsEAAAAMBAJ pg=PA98 lpg=PA98 dq=mcafee+software+history+as+shareware source=bl ots=FUrjroPLes sig=ouahfDSHnJEIH2MheprLDk_q6SQ hl=en sa=X ved=0ahUKEwj6rajdqbPPAhViL8AKHZ4cDx4Q6AEILjAJ#v=onepage q=mcafee%20software%20history%20as%20shareware f=false
I'm not sure where the writers are going with this. We understand the implications of what was done in present time as the outcome could be quite different. But back then code released in this fashion could easily be overlooked. No one would really care, especially if there was already a shareware/freeware anti-virus program that was popular.

I used an 80286 (commonly known as a 286) PC with a16-bit microprocessor, 40 megabyte hard drive with a 2400 baud modem that was connected to the phone line in 1993 or so.
I logged on to various local BBS services using a piece of software that came with the machine.
It had DOS (version 4.x) installed on it and a GUI called GeoWorks. It didn't even have Windows. At that time WordPerfect for DOS was used for word processing, Lotus 123 (later surpassed by Quattro) was the spreadsheet and another popular program was Harvard Graphics.

Yeah but I don't know of a train that goes from Toronto to NY so I treat it as an error.

"From Toronto Union Station: Toronto, Aldershot, Niagara Falls, Buffalo and New York on board the Maple Leaf"
Thank you. I know the area very well!

There are numerous buildings associated with Consumer's Gas in Old Town Toronto.
The main Consumer's Gas Building is located on 19 Toronto Street:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumers%27_Gas_Building
This is not visible in the photograph posted.
There is also the Consumer Gas Company Station A, which was located at 51 Parliament Street at Mill Street. It's now the headquarters for TPS 51 Division. This is also not visible in this photograph.
There was another another Consumer Gas Building at 26 Berkeley St, which is now the Canadian Stage Company:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Stage_Company
Quoted from this link:
"The historic Berkeley Street Theatre complex contains two performance spaces, as well as a large rehearsal space, props and wardrobe facilities, and the companys administrative offices. The Berkeley site was originally built by the Consumers Gas Corporation in 1887 as part of a gas pumping station complex. The Berkeley Downstairs Theatre was originally a pump room and served in that capacity until 1955, when Consumers Gas moved their production out of downtown Toronto."
I believe is is this building that can be seen just east of the Elias Rogers amp; Co.
Another view of this particular building, which was located at The Esplanade and Berkeley can be seen here:
https://commons.m.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Elias_Rogers_Coal_%26_Wood_Co.jpg
Edit: corrected direction for building location (east not north)
If you search YT using these words, "grey's anatomy meredith cristina" you'll get a bunch of videos including the scene where Cristina tells Meredith she's her person.

This is pretty much a "this is my life now" for most Canadians.
When the Canadian dollar (CAD) is worth more than the US dollar (USD) it takes a US online retailer forever to lower their prices. However, when the reverse is true and the USD is worth more than CAD you can bet those US websites have it adjusted immediately.
Edit to add: This type of price tag is just a way of ensuring that the USD retailers can adjust the price at any time.
At some point she's going to have to defend her dissertation.

Some very good points here. Do you see the Greenbelt Plan in any way accommodating these?
What I mean is there are already issues with farming as you've pointed out. In your opinion does the Greenbelt Plan (or the Places to Grow Act) in anyway help address these?
I'm thinking that if the Greenbelt Plan isn't working and farming already has other issues, which may be increasing and that make it a very challenging lifestyle/career path then I think there's an even bigger problem here.

I'd argue that farming isn't a dying occupation. It's just that farmland has been under constant assault from development, skyrocketing land values, and speculators.
I was thinking more along the lines that farming has ceased to be profitable years ago as more food was being imported and sold cheaper at grocery stores. This, along with droughts, pest problems and other reasons for bad crop outcomes meant that more were leaving this type of work. It wasn't seen as profitable and too risky so parents in farming families were encouraging their children to pick other careers.
Another issue, albeit a very rare one is the tobacco farmers like those in the Simcoe, Ontario area. As the pressure to reduce smoking increases the need for tobacco decreases. I believe some farmers have switched to growing asparagus in this area as this grows well in soil normally used for tobacco. But this may not be as profitable. So in this case it's market demand, or lack thereof that might put these farmers out of business.

FYI - before it was the Grand and Toy it was Mountain Equipment Co-Op.
Edit to add: and the coffee shop was the late, great Britnell's Bookstore.

My (perhaps overly simplistic) understanding of this is that it's main purpose is to increase urban density, that is to build housing like condos that have a smaller footprint and can house hundreds of people rather than a dozen or so in the same space. These are to be in an already built up urban environment, which would cut costs on implementing services (municipal like water, roadways, transportation and federal like postal services).
The flip side of this is to protect farmland from being used to develop new housing subdivisions, which would cost a lot of money to add new to services to. This is also to promote locally grown food in the farmland areas, which are no longer being used for new subdivisions.
However I seriously doubt this is the case. Developers are making money putting up poorly built condos in overly dense areas in order to quickly cash in on this. I don't think proper impact or environmental studies are being completed. Transit and transportation are suffering as a result. Also there's now an incredible strain on the infrastructure (evident in water mains breaking, electrical outages, pot holes) that no one seems to notice or care about.
Further, I don't know how much support there is for farmers, whether that includes those currently in this occupation or recruiting new people to start working is this area. I thought farming was a dying occupation and in many cases new generations have left as there's no future in it. I don't think this Growth Plan is opening up so many new opportunities that people are flocking to farming. The growth industry seems to be condo construction.
In addition, there's already been a few instances in which regions have tried to circumvent the Growth Plan:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Growth_Plan_for_the_Greater_Golden_Horseshoe#Official_Plan_Amendment_Case_Studies
And various criticisms have been put forth:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Growth_Plan_for_the_Greater_Golden_Horseshoe#Criticisms

I think she's fortunate to have found others with a similar interest given that she grew up in Regina, Saskatchewan. I think her brother was also interested in the same things so this may have increased their chances of finding likeminded individuals. It's almost universal that teenagers are interested in socializing in ways that include music, alcohol, drugs, sex, etc.

I love how she handles herself with the business, stating in the meeting that she doesn't do administrative work when it's suggested she compile the records, that she's a partner in the company and her name's on the door and then basically walking out of the meeting.
That type of behaviour must have been almost unheard of for a woman in the work place of that time period. Of course, so would have been her accomplishments.

I think part of the whole "start over" thing regardless of why is to cut all ties with your former life including changing your name (it would make it difficult to maintain your medical or academic credentials as noted above), leave your family, friends and to move to another state.
Once you've relocated you're expected to "lie low" or your cover would be blown. This is to protect you. Although working as a physician is not generally considered to be high profile there could be situations in your job where you are required to speak to the press, have your photo taken for some fundraising thing, etc. If this were the case with Jo she would likely have to say something to the hospital administration as to why she can't do this or she would be exposed. But it's a television show so they can bend reality in any way that they want!
Edit: clarity

Sometimes this depends on culture as well. For example, Italian families often let their underage children drink wine with dinner. But as for supplying them with alcohol to party with their friends, perhaps not so much.

First born children almost always have the second to largest bedroom. In a typical 3 bedroom house the parents have the largest, the first born the second largest and the youngest sibling the smallest room. If there's more children the oldest gets their own room and the others must share depending on gender.

I've heard many mothers say their first born child is their favourite. Not saying anyone's negative experience as a first born is invalid.
"Most parents have a favourite child and it's likely to be their first-born, study finds"
http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/study-finds-more-than-two-thirds-of-parents-have-a-favourite-child-and-its-probably-their-first-born-a6978911.html
There are other studies out there with similar results.
Often all the resources do into the first born and they're most likely to succeed later in life. Subsequent children are almost like an after thought. The first born passes all the milestones, like walking and talking, graduating from school, etc. first. When the others do the same it's not as big a deal. Most first borne have many photos taken of them as children. Other subsequent siblings often less so.
Two sports examples I can think of: Wayne Gretzky, great hockey player and first born. His other brothers didn't even make it to the NHL. Another sports example: John McEnroe, first born and an extremely successful tennis player. Younger brother Patrick didn't come close. Other younger brother Mark didn't even bother trying to play tennis.
I'm an only child so I'm just an observer of this phenomena.
The touchpad on the laptop is obviously faulty.

Odd, I learned about it in high school in Montreal.
I'm in Ontario so there was a heavy British influence in our history curriculum.
There's a famine memorial at Grosse Ile:
http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/lhn-nhs/qc/grosseile/index.aspx
And an excellent documentary, "The Coffin Ship Hannah" (http://www.tvpassport.com/series/the-coffin-ship-hannah/231354), which follows some Irish decadents currently residing in Montreal as they trace their roots back to Ireland. I highly recommend it.

As I see it the upvote is an implicit "I agree". You don't really need an explanation. But perhaps some exposition might be useful.
The downvote tells you nothing other than perhaps someone disagrees or doesn't like what you posted (found it offensive, for example).
When someone neither upvotes or downvotes little information about their perspective is conveyed other than perhaps they have no option.
We also have no way of knowing how many have read any one post overall. This could be an interesting metric.
Perhaps if the upvote/downvote both required comments then we could engage in a more progressive discourse.

WRITING.TITLE: Why doesn't Reddit remove the downvote button, which would hopefully encourage those who are just using it to disagree to instead explain their viewpoint in a comment?

May be they will get few more locations to set up discounted fare accounts, after all they will have to do something with those collectors that they wont need. May be it will be done via mail, or even online.who knows..
I believe you need documentation to be approved for the discount. This needs to be done by a person. In person. One who is trained to examine the requisite documents not collect fairs in the booth.

Quoted from article, "The value of having Presto for seniors and students who routinely ride the TTC is that theyre able to add a concession on the self-service fare card. This is a feature that allows customers to apply discounts. By default, the card is set to the adult fare, and in order to have their discount applied, riders only have one option: they have to visit Davisville station. While making the trip to Davisville is a one-time burden to get approved for discounted fares, having only the one option raises concerns for people who rely on transit to travel through the GTA, especially those with mobility issues"
So you have to pay to get to the Davisville station (if it's not already your stop) in order to get the discount? Spend money to save money.

there's so many classist implications with 'sophisticated and worldly'. do you mean rich/middle class?
Not necessarily. Just someone who can show Ian there's a different world out there. It could be something completely different like joining the Peace Corp and doing volunteer work in a developing nation.
I don't recall anyone begrudging Lip for trying to make his life different by going to college.

I can see (and agree with to a certain extent) the appeal to have them as endgame. However, I'd be concerned that Ian would have very little to learn from Mickey, at least in a good way. If Ian were to meet someone more sophisticated and worldly I believe it would be healthier for him long term. Now if Mickey comes back they could maintain a close, supportive friendship that would be beneficial to both (but probably not as emotionally satisfying to the viewers). I think Mickey knows Ian the best and vice versa. But I don't know if this means they should be together.

Lendl was considered to be a joke on the tour at the time. When he finally won the US Open after making it to the finals for the 3 previous years he was so overcome he ran into the tunnel used to access the court and puked.

Joe is an idea man, a visionary. He does not need to program anything any more than he needs to do administrative tasks, balance the books, etc.
How has he achieved anything in his career thus far? He surrounds himself with talented people that he poaches ideas from and turns them into money making ventures.
I'm not saying he doesn't have any skills. It's just that his skill set does not require that he's able to create a product or service. He hires other people to do that. He knows how to maneuvure, manipulate and market it.
